questions.question:
Question 1: A 52-year-old man has come to the emergency complaining of a burning type of chest pain. 
Comment on his ECG recording shown below.
questions.explanation:
The above ECG strip shows normal sinus rhythm. The features in this ECG that suggest this diagnosis are as follows: • The QRS complexes are narrow (<120 ms or 3 small squares) which implies that the impulse is 
supraventricular and is conducted via the normal conduction pathway. • Each QRS complex is preceded by a P wave. This means that all the atrial depolarizations that 
arise in the sinus node are conducted to the ventricles. 840 
Sold by @itachibot • The PR interval is constant for all the impulses and is normal (<200 ms) in duration. • The RR interval is constant which implies a regular rhythm. 841 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: All of the following are supraventricular tachycardias except:
questions.explanation:
Premature ventricular beats are a type of ventricular tachycardias, not supraventricular 
tachycardias. Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of >100 beats/min. It can be classified based on the site of 
origin of the cardiac impulse as follows: • Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) originate above the ventricles, that is, in the sinoatrial 
node, atria, or the atrioventricular node. Supraventricular tachycardias include: • Tachycardias originating from the atrium: • Sinus tachycardia- from the SA node • Focal atrial tachycardia • Multifocal atrial tachycardia • Atrial flutter • Atrial fibrillation • Tachycardias originating from the AV node: • Junctional tachycardia- automaticity within AV Node • AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT) • Tachycardia associated with accessory atrioventricular pathways: atrioventricular reentry 
tachycardia (AVRT) • Ventricular tachycardias originate from the ectopic foci or the reentry pathways in the 
ventricles. Ventricular tachycardias include: • Premature ventricular beats • Ventricular tachycardia (VT) 842 
Sold by @itachibot • Monomorphic VT- Very rapid monomorphic VT is also known as ventricular flutter • Polymorphic VT- associated with Torsades de pointes • Ventricular fibrillation

questions.question:
Question 3: 829 
Sold by @itachibot ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the 
following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is 
suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology: • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an 
example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with 
digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT. The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease. Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These 
impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast 
conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the 
ECG. Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These 
impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow 
QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like: • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: 843 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which is the most common supraventricular tachyarrhythmia?
questions.explanation:
The most common supraventricular arrhythmia is sinus tachycardia. It can either be physiological 
or pathological. Physiological sinus tachycardia is seen in exercise, fever, anemia, 
hyperthyroidism, etc. Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias are those supraventricular tachycardias that occur with 
sudden onset and termination, they are non-sustained arrhythmias (lasts < 30 seconds). They 
include AVNRT, AVRT, and atrial tachycardias. The most common sustained (lasts > 30 seconds) arrhythmia is atrial fibrillation. Junctional tachycardia originates from ectopic foci in the AV node. It is an uncommon 
tachycardia. 844 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 49-year-old woman was brought to the emergency with complaints of dizziness, shortness 
of breath, and palpitations. ECG showed tachyarrhythmia with narrow QRS complex and 
irregular RR intervals. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
ECG showing tachyarrhythmia with a narrow QRS complex suggests a supraventricular 
tachycardia. An irregular RR interval is seen with the following supraventricular tachycardias: • Atrial fibrillation • Multifocal atrial tachycardia • Atrial flutter/ atrial tachycardia with variable block The ECG below shows atrial fibrillation. Note the narrow QRS complexes and irregular RR 
intervals. Disappearacne of P-wave is another feature. 845 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol 
binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves. This 
is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry 
circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 
100-160/min. Risk factors for developing AF include: • Age- usually above 60 years of age • Underlying heart disease • Hypertension • Diabetes mellitus • Obesity • Sleep apnea • Post-cardiac surgery • Inflammatory pericarditis Acute precipitating factors for AF include: • Hyperthyroidism • Acute alcohol intoxication • Acute illness like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism

questions.question:
Question 7: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic 
therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the 
following drugs can be used to treat his condition? 831 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
846 
Sold by @itachibot The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are 
suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered 
in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease. Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation: In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking 
the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization: • Flecainide • Propafenone • Disopyramide In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act 
by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period: • Amiodarone • Dofetilide • Sotalol • Ibutilide

questions.question:
Question 8: A 60-year-old man who is on treatment for chronic AF presents with nausea, dizziness, and 
anorexia. He has a regular heart rate of 50/min. The most likely cause is:
questions.explanation:
A patient of atrial fibrillation usually has an irregular heart rate of >100/ min but this patient 
presents with a regular slow heart rate. The most likely cause of slow regular heart rate in chronic 
AF is digitalis toxicity. Symptoms such as nausea, anorexia are also suggestive of digitalis toxicity. Digitalis lowers the AV nodal conduction by stimulating the vagal nerve endings leading to 
increased vagal tone. Hence digitalis toxicity can cause AV nodal block. This leads to a junctional 
escape rhythm taking over the ventricles causing slow and regular heart rate. 847 
Sold by @itachibot Digitalis toxicity can also lead to a variety of arrhythmias as it increases the intracellular calcium 
levels increasing the risk of tachyarrhythmias.

questions.question:
Question 9: ECG of a patient who was brought to the casualty due to severe chest pain followed by 
syncope is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? 832 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter. The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR 
intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves, known as 
flutter waves. In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV 
ratio is 2:1. In the above ECG, the rhythm is atrial flutter 4:1 block with an atrial rate of about 270 
and a ventricular rate of 68/min. The image below shows sawtooth shaped waves in atrial flutter.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for 
the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pulmonary disease and the ECG showing different p wave 
morphologies are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia. Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) occurs due to impulses arising from multiple abnormal foci in 
the atria. This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different 
morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute 
illness. Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic 
abnormalities. Calcium-channel blockers and radiofrequency ablation of the AV node are the 
other treatment modalities. 848 
Sold by @itachibot The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals, hence it can be atrial 
fibrillation or multifocal atrial tachycardia. The next step is to look at the p waves. Multifocal 
atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by 
arrows in the image). Whereas, in atrial fibrillation, there would be no distinct p waves seen.

questions.question: Question 11: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias do not include:
questions.explanation:
Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias do not include atrial fibrillation. Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias are tachycardias that occur with sudden onset and 
termination, they are not sustained arrhythmias. They include • AVNRT • AVRT • Atrial tachycardia Whereas, atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia among supraventricular 
tachycardias. Features suggestive of PSVT: • Narrow complex tachycardia at 150 bpm • No visible P waves • Pseudo R’ waves due to retrograde atrial activation The given ECG shows pseudo R' waves: 849 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 32-year-old man is brought to the casualty after he developed sudden onset dyspnea, chest 
pain, and palpitations at a party. His blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. His ECG is shown 
below. What is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.explanation:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows: • Narrow QRS complexes • No visible p waves • Pseudo R' waves in V1 lead Adenosine is the preferred drug in stable paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Treatment of PSVT: In hemodynamically unstable patients, QRS-synchronous DC cardioversion should be done. In hemodynamically stable patients, 1. Mechanical measures: These maneuvers result in an acute increase in the vagal tone which 
decreases AV conduction and terminates the arrhythmia. They include the following: • Valsalva maneuver • Lowering the head between the knees • Coughing • Splashing cold water on the face • Breath-holding • Carotid sinus massage 2. Pharmacologic therapy: • Adenosine- it is the first-line agent. It blocks conduction across the AV node and terminates the 
SVT. It is given as a 6-18 mg bolus • Calcium channel blockers- verapamil and diltiazem 850 
Sold by @itachibot • Beta-blockers- esmolol, propranolol, and metoprolol • IV Procainamide- it is administered if the tachycardia is being mediated through an accessory 
pathway. It facilitates the AV conduction and therefore causes an initial increase in rate. 
Therefore, it is given after administering calcium channel blockers or beta-blockers. The given ECG shows pseudo R' waves:

questions.question:
Question 13: The ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already 
given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the 
next best step of management?
questions.explanation:
The given ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with absent P wave is 
suggestive of paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next best step in the management of 
a patient with unstable vitals (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) is synchronized 
cardioversion. 851 
Sold by @itachibot Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice in unstable PSVT patients, in which shocks 
are delivered with the defibrillator/monitor in synchronized mode with an initial energy level of 
100J. Synchronization times the delivery so that it is given at the peak of the QRS complex. If the shock occurs in the ST segment or the T wave (unsynchronized), it can precipitate a more 
serious arrhythmia such as ventricular fibrillation. Synchronized cardioversion 
Defibrillation Used in ventricular tachycard

ventricular tachycardiawith a

h the R wave (in absolute refr

sic: 50-100 J Monophasic: 360 JBiphasic:1 
20-200 J Other options: Option A: In the absence of hemodynamic instability, a repeat dose of injection adenosine 
(maximum of 12mg) could be attempted. Option B: IV Amiodarone is rarely used in the acute management of PSVT. Instead, it is used as 
an alternative to calcium channel blockers in chronic suppressive therapy. Option D: Defibrillation is only done for ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular 
tachycardia.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed a narrow complex, regular 
tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160 BPM. His blood pressure is 96/68 mmHg. 
What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
852 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showing narrow QRS complex 
regular tachycardia without P waves are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia 
(PSVT). The next step in the management of PSVT in a hemodynamically stable (systolic blood 
pressure >90 mm Hg) patient is vagotonic maneuvres such as carotid sinus massage or 
Valsalva maneuver. Carotid sinus massage can be considered in the absence of carotid bruits and no history of stroke. 
If vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used. Non-DHP calcium channel blockers and beta blockers are second-line pharmacological agents in 
the management of PSVT. They can cause hypotension before and after terminating the 
arrhythmia. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg or mean arterial 
pressure <65 mm Hg), immediate QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is necessary. The treatment algorithm for PSVT is described in the flowchart below:

questions.question:
Question 15: 835 
Sold by @itachibot A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department in a state of 
unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best 
step in the management of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes an unconscious patient, who is hemodynamically unstable 
(systolic BP <90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure <65 mmHg). The ECG shows a narrow QRS 
complex tachycardia (heart rate of 188 BPM) with regular RR interval and absent P waves, 
characteristic of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next step in management is 
QRS-synchronized DC cardioversion. Shown below is the algorithm for the management of supraventricular tachycardia: 853 
Sold by @itachibot Options A, B, and C are all used in stable cases. Vagal maneuvers like carotid massage or Valsalva 
are tried first followed by IV Adenosine. If these are ineffective, IV Verapamil, Diltiazem, or Beta 
blockers are used. Synchronized cardioversion

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is false about accessory pathways?

options.a: Bundle of Kent has antegrade conduction

questions.explanation:
Retrograde conduction via accessory pathways does not cause preexcitation. Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and 
ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways: Antegrade conduction: • Occurs from the atria to the ventricle 854 
Sold by @itachibot • The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the 
normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay. • This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles 
and thus a wide QRS complex. • Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT Retrograde conduction: • Occurs from the ventricle to the atria. • The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria 
through the accessory pathway. • Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow QRS 
complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the 
accessory pathway. • Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following is the most common reentrant tachycardia caused by an accessory 
pathway?
questions.explanation:
The most common reentrant tachycardia caused by an accessory pathway is orthodromic AV 
reentry. Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and 
ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways: Antegrade conduction: • Occurs from the atria to the ventricle • The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the 
normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay. • This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles 
and thus a wide QRS complex. • Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT Retrograde conduction: • Occurs from the ventricle to the atria. • The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria 
through the accessory pathway. • Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow 
QRS complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the 
accessory pathway. • Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT. AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT) is not caused by an accessory pathway. It involves tissues 
with different conduction speeds within the AV node or just adjacent to the AV node, known as 
the fast pathway and the slow pathway. This is known as dual AV nodal physiology. 855 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient's ECG shows a short PR interval and delta wave. Additional findings include atrial 
fibrillation and rapid ventricular rate. He is hemodynamically stable. All of the following 
drugs can be used in the management except:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient with WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation. Rate-slowing drugs such as non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, verapamil, 
diltiazem), beta-blockers, and digoxin are contraindicated in these patients. They increase the 
refractoriness of the AV node with minimal or no effect on the accessory pathway. This can lead to 
faster ventricular rates, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation. The ECG below shows a short PR interval (<120 ms) and delta waves in WPW syndrome.

questions.question: Question 19: The most common location of the accessory pathway in WPW syndrome is:
questions.explanation:
The most common location of an accessory pathway in WPW syndrome is on the left free wall. It 
is present between left atrium and free wall of left ventricle. 856 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: All are true about the condition that is diagnosed by the given ECG except: 837 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Can be seen in asymptomatic individuals
options.d: Caused by an abnormal accessory pathway

questions.explanation:
The given ECG is suggestive of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Its prevalence decreases 
with age. The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows: • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms) • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave) • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds) • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave 
and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization 857 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and 
lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is as shown below. What is the best step in 
management?
questions.explanation:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval 
which are classically seen in Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome. In this patient, catheter 
ablation is the best for long-term management. Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and 
sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction 
(preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal 
accessory pathway). Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, 
thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is true regarding sick sinus syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Sick sinus syndrome is frequently seen in patients with concomitant atrial fibrillation. Sick sinus syndrome (or sinus node dysfunction) is a group of abnormal heart rhythms. It is a 
disorder of the sinoatrial node caused by impaired pacemaker function and impulse transmission. 
This leads to a combination of abnormal rhythms, including atrial bradyarrhythmias, atrial 
tachyarrhythmias, and sometimes a pattern of alternating bradycardia and tachycardia, known as 
tachy-brady syndrome. These irregular rhythms can cause symptoms such as palpitations, 
decreased tissue perfusion, subsequent fatigue, lightheadedness, pre-syncope, and syncope. The management of sick sinus syndrome includes identifying and correcting reversible factors, as 
an initial step. Some examples of reversible causes of Sinus Node Dysfunction include, • Hypothyroidism 858 
Sold by @itachibot • Sleep apnea • Anti-hypertensive medications eg. Beta-blockers • Anti-arrhythmic medications eg. Amiodarone, Procainamide Ambulatory ECG monitoring is required to diagnose as the symptoms are nonspecific. Treatment involves permanent pacing. Other options: Option A: The course of sinus node dysfunction is usually a slow progression over decades. In the 
early stages, most patients are asymptomatic. Option B: It occurs most commonly in elderly patients due to the gradual loss of SA node 
function. Option D: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in this condition. 859 
Sold by @itachibot Ventricular Arrhythmias and Heart Blocks
